title: Ticket #4535: Reject DAGs that try to write to read-only file systems
description:
On Tue, 12 Aug 2014, Tom Downes wrote:

I'm receptive to the idea that you can only do so much to stop stupid but...

I have 2 users who were running DAGs that were attempting to write to a read-only filesystem. I think these DAGs are bonked for their own special-snowflake reasons and it so happens that when they were first submitted long ago it was a rw filesystem. It got filled up along the way, brought down the cluster and I decided to make it read-only; these users did not change their jobs accordingly. But, at some point, these DAGs probably started up OK and successfully submitted jobs.

After upgrading to 8.2.2 today and rebooting to get a kernel patch installed, I found that after restarting the schedd, these condor_dagmans would get stuck in idle and condor_q was unresponsive to the point where I had to turn the tool multiplier up to 100 and run, e.g.. 

  condor_rm -constraint 'JobUniverse == 7' user

It did not go unnoticed that these tools now allow translate a username argument into the appropriate constraint, thanks.

strace -p pid_of_schedd showed a lot of hits involving the read-only filesystem and an error like -1 O_RDONLY (my strace output is lost to sands of time). It moved on from each error quickly but would move right on to another instance of the error (in one case a user had ~15 DAGs all making the same mistake).

So, it would be nice if condor_schedd could detect this problem and reject a DAG. I'm not sure if it was a DAG job trying to write to the filesystem or the condor_dagman itself but the fact that the JobUniverse=7 jobs were idling suggests it was the condor_dagman.

Okay, I'll make a gittrac ticket for this. We'll have to do some thinking about how things should work, and where the detection should happen. For example, if the problem is that the workflow log is on a read-only filesystem, DAGMan itself could detect that before submitting any jobs. If the dagman.out file is on a read-only filesystem, I think that would have to get detected in daemoncore.

Kent
remarks:
2015-Sep-22 11:51:34 by tpdownes:
In-person discussion Kent+Tom. We both think it's worthwhile to pursue ability of DAGMan to test writability of nodes.log file prior to submitting jobs because DAGMan simply won't know jobs are completing unless this file exists.

Targeting 8.5 series so prioritize at 3.
